Award.AwardTitle: DISSERTATION RESEARCH: Causes and consequences of flower color variation in Aquilegia coerulea
Award.AbstractNarration:
Genetic variation between individuals is ubiquitous across the tree of life, and a requirement for both adaptive and non-adaptive evolutionary change. Processes that affect the genetic variation within species can affect their evolutionary potential. Geographic differences in the strength and direction of natural selection lead to local adaptation of populations and the maintenance of genetic variation at a species level, even when variation would have otherwise have been lost. Although this process has potentially dramatic consequences for adaptation by natural selection, its relative importance in shaping the evolutionary fate of species is unknown. Rocky Mountain columbine grows at high elevations in the Southern Rockies, a region characterized by strong environmental gradients such as summer precipitation (i.e. monsoonal rain in the south and almost none in the north). The proposed research will identify variable genetic regions through whole-genome sequencing of hundreds of individuals across the species? distribution, and patterns of genetic variation will be used to identify those regions that are experiencing geographically variable natural selection. Greenhouse experiments will test whether precipitation could differentially affect fitness of variants for one trait that shows geographic variation, flower color.

The proposed research will provide important insight into how environmental differences across a species range affect genetic variation at the whole-genome level. This relationship is critical to understanding how biological diversity originates and is maintained through time in the face of a variable and changing environment. In light of rapid global climate change, such an understanding takes on particular significance. Training of students will result from this work.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project investigated the causes and consequences of flower color evolution in the columbine genus, Aquilegia. Populations of the Colorado State flower, Aquilegia coerulea, vary from pure deep blue to polymorphic for both blue and white to pure white in color. In polymorphic populations we found that genes that respond to heat stress were expressed at higher levels than in white flowered individuals. We found that indeed, blue-flowered individuals have hotter tissue temperatures than white-flowered individuals when in full sun. We further showed that blue-flowered individuals transpire more water when in the sun. Thus, blue-flowered individuals are likely at a disadvantage in populations where water is limiting. This finding supports the hypothesis that summer rainfall is a causal factor in the predominant flower color of populations across the species range where we find white-flowered populations where summer rainfall is low and blue-flowered populations where summer rainfall is high.

We further investigated the causes of flower color variation across multiple species of Aquilegia, including nearly all species that occur in North America. Flower color varies across species from blue, red, white and yellow. The evolutionary history of the genus suggests that evolutionary transitions in flower color have been from blue to red, or from either of these colors to white or yellow. Because each of these transitions are inferred to have occurred multiple times in the genus, this system gave us the opportunity to test whether a specific transition has occurred due to similar genetic changes. We found that across four transitions from yellow to white flowers were highly correlated with an increase in expression of a single gene, CCD4, which degrades the yellow carotenoid pigment. Similarly, across two transitions from blue to red flowers, three genes showed consistent changes in gene regulation. One of these genes had been previously found in multiple other systems with blue-red transitions but we also identified two other genes. One of these likely modifies the anthocyanin pigment and the other likely modifies the pH environment in the subcellular compartment where it resides (the vacuole). Both of these modification very likely affect flower color. In transitions from making anthocyanins to not, we found a large number of genes in the anthocyanin pathway had their expression down-regulated. This finding strongly suggests that a common trans-regulatory gene is responsible. Lastly we identified multiple genes without gene expression differences in comparisons of flower color transitions but that had highly correlated gene sequences. In these instances, changes to the genes’ amino acid sequence likely cause changes to protein function.

This project may have direct broader impacts to the field of floral horticulture. The breeding of new floral colors is of great importance to this industry and our results suggest that changes in expression or amino acid sequence to just a few genes are of particular importance in producing specific colors.
